title: wales stricter lockdown measures
story: WALES is tightening their coronavirus lockdown measures even further to stop people staying outside for longer than they need to.The Welsh government announced today it was cracking down on people lingering outdoors after going out for an essential reason.Stay at home advice in Wales has been given an added requirement for people not to leave or remain away from their homes for too long.They are still allowed to go out to get food or medicine, do exercise or essential work, but they cant stay any longer than absolutely necessary.It comes amid concerns more people are flouting lockdown rules as the weather warms up.The Welsh government are also considering a fresh crackdown on people visiting their second homes, and they will be asking policeextra restrictions are needed.Other rules have been formally relaxed, and click and collect services are now allowed to open as long as they can apply two metre social distancing rules.People with particular health conditions or disabilities have also had rules relaxed so they can leave home for exercise more than once a day.The changes will come into effect tomorrow, as First Minister Mark Drakeford gears up to follow Scotlands lead by laying down a blueprint for Wales to leave lockdown.Mr Drakeford will announce the countrys plan for exit later today with seven questions which will determine how and when measures can be relaxed.Mr Drakeford said: The restrictions are staying in place, which mean you must stay at home to save lives and protect the NHS.Over the last few months, we have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.This approach has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and it has also helped to save many lives.The changes we are introducing supplement the rules already in force but they respond to some challenges being faced in parts of the country and by families throughout Wales.Our message has not changed – anyone can get coronavirus, anyone can spread it. So please, stay home, protect the NHS, and save lives.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.People rushed to BQ after they opened all their stores today. Health Secretary Matt Hancock last night emphasized the importance of a four nation approach to easing lockdown restrictions.He said Scotlands plan was based off the UK Governments five key tests that must be met before the lockdown can be relaxed.The new measures come as Brits start to deal with lockdown fatigue and begin breaking social distancing measures by getting in cars and visiting parks.Traffic on roads continues to rise with thousands of people keen to get out in the sunshine, and new figures show shopping is up  per cent.Some stores have started to open back up, and stores such as BQ attracted massive queues of people wanting to try their hand at DIY projects.Londons Hyde Park was packed with young Brits exercising and relaxing in the sunshine, as temperatures soared up to C in the capital.The Welsh government is concerned the warm weather will tempt more people to sneak away to second homes, andpolice forces think existing measures need to be strengthened the Welsh government is expected to do so.Downing Street has continually refused to set out its own exit strategy over concerns it could muddy the water and distract people from the stay at home advice. px,px, title: iran satellite launch ballistic missile uk government
story: Tehran this week announced it had blasted its first military satellite into space, in violation of international sanctions.And the Government today slammed the operation, which some fear could be a cover for testing ballistic missile technology.A Foreign Office spokesman said: Reports that Iran has carried out a satellite launch - using ballistic missile technology - are of signicant concern and inconsistent with UN Security Council Resolution .The UN has called upon Iran not to undertake any activity related to ballistic missiles designed to be capable of delivering nuclear weapons. Iran must abide by this.We have signicant and long-standing concerns, alongside our international partners, over Irans ballistic missile programme, which is destabilising for the region and poses a threat to regional security.Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corpssaid the satellite “Noor” - meaning Light - was in a -mile-high orbit, after a successful launch.The satellite was fired by a three-stage rocket which the IRGC said was powered by a combination of solid and liquid fuels.At the time of the launch the US secretary of state Mike Pompeo said the launch violated a UN security council resolution from .He said: “I think every nation has an obligation to go to the United Nations and evaluate whether this missile launch was consistent with that security council resolution.“I don’t think it remotely is, and I think Iran needs to be held accountable for what they have done.”Iran launched its first civilian satellite in .On the same day as the latest launch, Donald Trump piled the pressure on Iran by telling the US Navy to shoot down and destroy any and all Iranian gunboatsthey harass our ships at sea.Trump issued the warning after Iranian naval boats were filmed taunting US Navy warships in the Persian Gulf.Iranian speedboats were filmed last week harassing a US Navy ship in the Persian Gulf.The incidents serve a reminder that the coronavirus pandemic has not ended dangerous military rivalries around the world.

title: get right track trace programme coronavirus
story: The Governments new action plan to stop the spread of coronavirus and start to look at easing measures has to be watertight for it to work.Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced last night the test, track and trace programme to get the UK back on track as it fights coronavirus.But contact tracing will rely on having accurate data and an app, which has been one of the methods used around the world, could have major flaws.Tom Pressley of tech communications firm Everbridge warned any national contact tracing app could have serious chinks in its armour.Mr Pressley told The Sun Online: There are some flaws in taking a purely app based approach that the Government is going to have to try and solve.The solutions governments are looking at - they get one chance to get it right, so it has to be right the first time. assumes that the data people will upload is going to be reliable.It assumes that adoptionwill be universal... for it to be successful you need a take up of around  to  per cent.Relying on an app such as the one being developed by Apple and Google would also mean everyone would need to have a smartphone.But he warned only around  per cent of elderly people, who will need accurate information the most, have smartphones.Other countries who have already tried to introduce tracing apps have only had  to  per cent of the population download the app.Singapore, for example, introduced its TraceTogether app - but only a fth of the population has downloaded it, nowhere near enough for it to be effective.One of the solutions could be sending out text blasts which can both inform people of an outbreak in their area, and ask them for information about their circumstances including age, health conditions and symptoms.Texts could also be sent out to tell specic areas to self-isolate.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Everbridges communication technology has been tried and tested during natural disasters, such as Cyclone Dorian last year, and allows messages to be sent to those that need the information.Mr Pressley said: Weve been working with governments and businesses and stuck with this technology because it is robust and reliable and able to hit a critical mass of people.Thats not to say were going to blast everyone in the country, because the detail you want is to be able to localise some of these messages.If there is an outbreak around the corner we draw a map around that area of, say, a two miles radius, and we can then send out an instruction very quickly. tailor that specic message to specic people.Countries such as Norway have already started using the text alerts to tailor messages to particular groups of people, such as foreign nationals, who can be detected by their phones SIM card.It means any information can be sent out in the language the person speaks.Mr Pressley said: Are the Government really considering the dferent nuances of dferent demographics in a particular city or a dferent country Weve always had the philosophy of not leaving anyone behind.   Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman bundled car men bride kidnapping russia
story: The incident occurred at around .pm on Wednesday in the city of St Petersburg, Russia.Bride kidnapping is a practice in which a man kidnaps a woman he wants to marry, and it reportedly still continues in certain parts of Russian society.In the clip, a young woman is seen leaving an apartment block, reported to be on Telman Street, with her mother as three men exit a car with their faces covered.Two of the men restrain the mother while a third runs up behind and grabs the young woman.Both women can be heard screaming as the young women is bundled into the car, which drives off as soon as the doors are closed, leaving two of the men behind.The two men then run away, pursued by the mother and another man who has run out of the apartment block.The mothers screams can be heard continuing off-camera.Police later found a -year-old man with the -year-old woman in the city of Tikhvin, a three-hour drive from St Petersburg, Komsomolskaya Pravda reported.The man reportedly claimed the incident was part of a traditional abduction of the bride.He is thought to have kidnapped the same woman in February.Her relatives similarly contacted police on that occasion, but the woman declined to press charges, and the man was given a verbal warning, vesti.ru reported.The regional department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs is now said to be considering whether to pursue criminal proceedings.The man is reportedly facing charges for a crime against the freedom, honour and dignity of the person.The footage is not the first such clip to have made headlines in Russia recently.Last year, video showed a woman being bundled into a car the city of Vladikavkaz while the kidnappers friends sounded their car horns and let off celebratory gun shots.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bubbles friends lockdown sturgeon
story: PEOPLE could meet up in small “bubbles” of friends during the lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon has said.The First Minister of Scotland today suggested the public could decide on one key group of pals who they were allowed to see.Ms Sturgeon told BBC Radio Scotland’s Good Morning Scotland that Britain could follow the countries currently looking at expanding “households” to allow small gatherings of people.She said: “Some countries are starting to look at slightly expanding what people would define as their household – encouraging people who live alone to maybe match up with somebody  who is on their own or a couple of other people to have almost kind of bubbles of people.“And the key thing there is,you’re seeing maybe one or two more people outside your household, it’s got to be the same people on a day-to-day, week-to-week basis so you’re still limiting the ability for the virus to transmit.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.“Now, none of these are fixed decisions yet, but these are all the kind of things we’re trying to work through.”Currently the UK rules state that people should not meet up with anyone they do not live with.It comes one day after the Scottish leader urged the UK Government to treat people like grown ups as she shared her draft plans for ending Scotlands lockdown.The Scottish First Minister yesterday insisted that politicians should be frank with the public - after Government scientists said last night that social distancing could continue until .Her proposed plan for relaxing the lockdown included:Ms Sturgeon stressed the strict measures were still absolutely necessary, but said Scotland needs to chart a way forward to live with the virus over the coming months.

title: france restrict nicotine study claimed smoking stop coronavirus
story: FRANCE has restricted sales of nicotine substitutes after research suggested smoking may offer some protection against the coronavirus.The Health Ministry said it wanted to avoid stockpiling and to prevent the wrong use or overuse, of substitutes used to fight nicotine dependence.Under a decree, pharmacies are not allowed to sell more than a months worth of substitutes until May  when France is to begin easing coronavirus lockdown measures and reopening schools.The decree also said that online sales were suspended.French researchers are looking at whether nicotine patches can help patients with Covid- symptoms.It comes after a new study claimed fewer people hospitalised, or at home, with coronavirus were regular smokers compared to the general population.The team suggested that nicotine could prevent the virus from infecting cells or that nicotine was preventing the immune system from overreacting to the virus.But the World Health Organisation  has warned that cigarettes can actually increase the risk of contracting Covid- - and smokers may also already have lung disease or reduced lung capacity which would greatly increase risk of serious illness.Health minister Olivier Veran also hammered home the dangers of smoking and said than , people die each year in France from smoking related illnesses.A team of French researchers has written an interesting scientic article which tends to show that there are fewer patients in the population consuming nicotine - and therefore smokers - than in the rest of population, he told Parliament..But beware, this does not mean that tobacco protects. Tobacco kills.The study by researchers at Piti-Salptrire hospital in Paris, showed that smokers were less infected with the virus than other people.It also showed that nicotine could prevent the virus from entering cells.Researchers warned nevertheless that smokers who did become infected with coronavirus would develop more severe cases of the Covid- .To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: general sir nick carter provided a sense of hope why didnt we call in the army earlier
story: I DON’T know about you but I felt greatly reassured this week by the presence of General Sir Nick Carter at a government press briefing.Standing there in unorm, delivering crisp, authoritative information, the Chief of the Defence Staff gave me a sense of real hope.Finally, it was good to see an adult in charge, and for the first time I felt everything really was going to turn out all right in the end.There were no woolly, evasive tactics — instead, just clarity and common sense.Sir Nick, didn’t sugar-coat what we are all facing.He said Covid- was “the single greatest logistic challenge” he had seen in  years of service.He didn’t downplay the scale of the mountain we all still have to climb but his encouraging words stfened our resolve to Keep Calm And Carry On.It was like drinking a cool glass of water and, I swear, I felt the stress oozing out of my body.The Armed Forces have been playing a blinder.They have given invaluable help in setting up the Louisa Jordan Hospital in Glasgow and the new Nightingale hospitals across England, which were kitted out in a matter of weeks.To be honest, I would have brought in the Army a hell of a lot sooner and given them the task of procuring and distributing PPE so we could have avoided the woeful shortages that have seen nurses having to reuse flimsy aprons and even resort to wearing cagoules to protect themselves on the front line.Sir Nick also highlighted the work being done by the Army to counteract  information and scare tactics, especially some of the rubbish online, which is unsettling, isive and utterly irresponsible.With the typical humility that characterises the British Armed Forces, Sir Nick said the men and women under his command were simply there to support the heroic healthcare workers at the sharp end — both in the NHS and social care.He also paid tribute to the man of the moment, World War Two veteran Captain Tom Moore, who has raised more than £million for the NHS.Sir Nick said Tom “embodies the sense of service and duty ingrained in the military”.Indeed he does — and we are seeing examples of that sense of service and duty in all areas of the Armed Forces every single day.You just have to look at Army cadets such as -year-old Chris Johnson, from Warrington, Ches, who has been making PPE visors for NHS staff using his D printer at home.The RAF is flying in crucial protection equipment, and Army reservists are working to create technology that will make PPE delivery more joined-up and efficient.Of course, on top of the Covid- crisis, the Army, Navy and RAF still have their normal operational tasks to carry out.But just like our NHS and the police force, the Armed Forces have been subjected to horrendous budget cuts.These cannot be allowed to continue and must be reversed, even in the extremely tough economic future we all now face.I sincerely hope, when the dust settles and we are back to some kind of normality, that this Government and each one after it will realise the truly vital jobs are those being done by the men and women who work tirelessly to make and keep our lives safe.And that they are rewarded with respect, jobs for le — and stonking pay rises.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.ONE thing that never fails to lt my sprits when I am out for my once-a-day dog walk is the children’s rainbow drawings stuck on the windows and doors of the houses I pass and etched in chalk on paths and pavements.Even the littlest royal, Prince Louis, has been getting in on the act to show his support for our NHS and key workers.The joyful pictures of him with multi-coloured paint all over his hands, taken by proud mum Kate, are the perfect way to mark his second birthday.Along with big brother George and sister Charlotte, Louis is being home-schooled by his mum and dad who, like all parents, will have a new-found respect for teachers.William and Kate have been quietly and effectively doing their bit to help us feel more positive during these tough times.Their video calls to hospitals and schools, plus footage of their children joining in the Thursday night clap for carers, genuinely makes a dference.The Queen must take a lot of solace from her grandson and his near-perfect family.I hope it eases her worries about her husband’s health, the scandal over Andrew and concerns about Harry, who is so very far away.THERE are lots of seriously bad home haircuts at the moment.And I’m afraid I have added to the list after I attacked my long-suffering husband with the electric clippers.Poor Steve ended up like a newly shorn baa-lamb and narrowly avoided having both his ears lopped off.Luckily, he can’t see the back of his head.And, thankfully, hair grows back . . .I HAD to chortle at rumours this week that I am to sign up for the next series of Strictly.This. Will. Never. Happen.I adore the show and am glad it is on track toas usual later this year.But I know I would be very, very bad – and not in a funny Ed Ballsy way.I’d just be embarrassingly woeful. At the age of , I don’t want to be dragged around the dancefloor by the long-suffering Anton du Beck, showing off my knickers like Ann Widdecombe.I reckon the idea I might be involved in Strictly all started because of the ­glorious pro dancer Luba Mushtuk, who was paired with Olympic rower James Cracknell, last year and exited far too soon.We met each other at the Jason Vale health retreat, below, in February, where people go to recharge their batteries.It feels like a letime ago that we were all enjoying long walks, yoga and exercise classes, making new friends along the way.Luba very kindly gave us all a Strictly masterclass. I’ll never forget the hilarious lessons out in the sunshine – with a view of the lakes and hearing everyone’s laughter.Although I really enjoyed myself, it made me realise I could never, ever be a contestant on Strictly.My role is to watch the show from the comfort of my sofa with a large glass of wine and a jumbo bag of Revels.It is easy to criticise the ministers and health experts fighting Covid-.They must make le-or-death decisions with the information available and haven’t always got it right.But they are also human beings.This week England’s Deputy Chief Medical Officer, Dr Jenny Harries, told me she had been struck down by the virus, probably the day after Prime Minister Boris Johnson tested positive, and it left her feeling frail.With classic understatement, she called it an “unpleasant” experience.She was looked after by her children, one of whom is a junior doctor, and had to stay off work for ten days.This will have given her even greater insight into the disease and empathy with patients and their families.But it also makes us realise that behind the daily pm briefings are real people just trying to do their best.I’M still baffled by what to do when it comes to wearing a face mask.EvenI could get one, I don’t want to deprive a worker in the NHS, a care home or public transport, as these grafters are the priorities.We are told by some thatwe stay at home, and social-distance when we go out to the shops or for a bit of exercise, we don’t need to wear a mask.But that can feel problematicyou’re out shopping or on a bus or train.I will be making my own mask from the simple DIY instructions printed in The Sun earlier this week – it will be much better than nothing.But right now, there’s confusion and doubt, and it must be cleared up fast.NO ONE wants to put extra pressure on the NHS, and figures show we haven’t been going to AE or phoning ambulances unless we’re severely ill, which is laudable.But you can go too far.I would urge anyone who happens upon a lump or something suspicious to get help right away.Cancer specialists report a drastic fall in the number of people seeking help and fear a huge increase in cancer cases.So don’t think you are being a nuisance.A drastic, unexplained weight loss, a lump or change in a breast, or anything amiss with the testicles, must NEVER be ignored.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we title: scientists dont agree coronavirus thinking properly
story: SOME scientists tell us we should definitely wear face masks when we are outside while others say they are a complete waste of time. In Sweden, they say that everyone should rub up against one another when shopping, while in France they are ­ordering everyone to stay inside for another three weeks. Some boffins say that testing is the answer to Covid-. Some say it isn’t.Some say  is the age where you most need to worry. Some say it’s .Some say the virus will be wiped out by summer weather. Others say it won’t.And meanwhile, everyone is sitting at home thinking, “Can you lot make up your bloody minds.”But that’s the point of science. There should never be a ­consensus.Everything should constantly move as new discoveries are made. Emc until someone proves that it doesn’t.My colleague Rod Liddle explained last weekend that when the first atom bomb was about to be tested, none of the utterly brilliant men who’d designed it could agree on what would happen.Some said the explosion would be small. Some said it would be massive.One thought it might set the ­atmosphere on fire. One said it wouldn’t work at all.Today, we are told that all of science is agreed on global warming.We hear it IS happening and it IS our fault. No argument is allowed.History has taught us that this is ­dangerous.A hundred years ago, someone came up with a new idea called eugenics.The idea was that the human race was doomed because too many black and ­stupid people were having babies.We can see now that this is lazy, racist nonsense but back then it was a ­dferent story.Boffins at all the most prestigious ­institutions in America were captivated by it.They worked on it at Yale and ­Hard. Millions was spent on research.The greatest minds were taken in, Nobel Prize winners among them.HG Wells supported it and so did George Bernard Shaw and Alexander ­Graham Bell.Legislation was passed to promote it.Winston Churchill believed in it, as did US presidents Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow ­Wilson.So just like global warming, we had an idea backed by leading politicians and many top celebrities.And anyone who said it was stupid was told to shut up.“We have science on our side” they screamed.Yeah, but they also had Hitler on their side.He believed so ­passionately in eugenics, he came up with the Aryan Nation, built concentration camps and murdered six ­million Jews.Be glad then that scientists can’t agree on what to do about Covid-.It shows they are ­thinking. When they say they all agree, it shows they’re not.EVERY European country has dferent ideas about which businesses can re-open next week and which ones cannot.But they’d all really like to give the green light to one thing: Hairdressers.I realise, of course, that everyone has now reverted to their original hair colour and that in Scotland it’s easy to spot the ginger roots of recession.But I just can’t see why this matters so much. And then I saw that picture of Pierce Brosnan . . .TO mark something called Earth Day , Prince Charles has said that in future we should put the “people and the planet” first.Hmmm. Not sure that’s going to work. Because what the planet wants and what people want are two very dferent things.What people want is to be warm and comfortable. We also want to be happy, which means we want a new sofa from DFS, a nice car, a couple of holidays every year and a fridge full of ice-cold beer.Charles would probably argue that the “people” he’s talking about are those who live in mud huts in Africa and Asia and bits of South America.Right. So what do they want  Well, I’m fairly sure thatyou asked them, they’d say they’d like a new sofa, a nice car, a holiday or two and a fridge full of ice-cool beer.That means we must build power stations and roads for them.We must dam their rivers and pull down their jungles to make way for sewerage and water pipes and factories and hospitals and shopping centres.I’m fairly confident then thatwe put people first, the planet is going to feel like we’ve trodden on its toe.I WAS out on my tractor this week, doing a safe and steady mph on a narrow country lane, when I noticed in one of the seven rear view mirrors that behind me, there was a small army of cyclists who couldn’t get past.Ooh, I was happy.I was so happy in fact, that when I got home, I drove right past the drive so that I could keep them all behind me a little bit longer.Payback.It’s so, so sweet.COUNCIL chiefs in Manchester say that the city has been so lovely and quiet these past few weeks that they are thinking of banning cars for ever.Really  You want to stop all those Cheshire boys coming into the city centre on a Friday night with their Ferraris and Bentleys Good luck with that.THIS week, we read about a builder who’d kept his we happy by turning his dumper truck into a luxury bath.He’d even used a drill attachment to create bubbles.Very clever but I knew a man in Doncaster back in the day who made his kids a swimming pool out of a skip.He tilted it so there was a deep end and even put a brazier underneath, so it was fully heated.WHETHER you’re doing a house-party or video conferencing with colleagues, it’s critically important you get the background correct.Tory MPs using Skype to do interviews on the evening news usually put themselves in front of a book case.This tells us they are wise and well read.Celebrities usually make sure there’s a bit of zebra skin in the shot and a pickled shark or two on the wall.This week, my friend Trinny Woodall hosted a live online make-up tutorial from her bathroom.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Doubtless she made sure the background was spick and span. And it was. Right up to the moment when her partner, Charles, , walked into the back of shot. Naked. Stuff like that can happen to anyone who’s not careful.Last week, I hosted an online general knowledge quiz. No one got any of the questions right. They were all too busy staring at the mountain of champagne over my shoulder.Tragically, I’d bought it for the guests at my th birthday party a couple of weeks ago. title: stricter lockdown measures flout rules
story: Five weeks after the severe restrictions were introduced, roads, beaches and parks have started filling up again.At a news conference, Home Secretary Priti Patel will produce official data that proves rule-breaking is on the increase.On Friday, the Welsh government announced tougher measures to stop non-essential trips.The move came as:The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. transport use has ticked up in a way that suggests something more is going on and that has set off alarm bells.“We know it has been hard but everyone needs to stick with it.“The more people comply with the rules, and we slow the spread of this virus, the sooner we can think about easing rules.”But there are signs a UK-wide approach is splintering.Nicola Sturgeon suggested Scots could soon be allowed to meet a small “bubble” of friends or family.And Northern Ireland’s First Minister Arlene Foster said less-affected areas should be allowed to end restrictions sooner.But Wales announced tougher measures.Officials unveiled seven criteria that must be met, two more than the UK-wide plan.It added people must “not leave or remain away” from their homes for longer than absolutely necessary.The Welsh government is also considering a fresh crackdown on second home visits.Ms Foster told the BBC: “We have been working together as four nations, continuing to decide what is the best keep up social distancing and to stay at homethey develop symptoms.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon says her government will be the ones to decide how to exit the lockdown because the “science will never be exact”.WALESNO easing without  days of consistent falling hospital admissions, which could be in mid-May.Then, a traffic light system would go through red, amber and green stages.Each would be triggered by factors including economic benefits, risk of further infections and how easily the lockdown could resume.N. IRELANDEXIT from lockdown could take a dferent pace from the rest of the UK, says First Minister Arlene Foster.The Northern Ireland executive will look at hospital and intensive care admissions along with numbers of deaths and take into account the state of lockdown measures in the Republic of Ireland.Health Secretary Matt Hancock continued to insist the focus was on stopping the spread of the virus and it was too soon to end lockdown restrictions.But he was comfortable with some businesses reopening.A No source said: “We know there’s only a certain amount of this that the public can take.“That’s why ministers want to make progress as quickly as possible on the five conditions the Government has set out.“By taking the right steps at the right time and going into lockdown when the scientic evidence justied that step, we were able to ensure compliance was at its highest when it mattered.“As a result we have flattened the curve and stopped further spread of the disease.”England’s chief medical officer Chris Whitty played down the prospect of regional iations.But more and more are not.We understand the temptation.We are all stir crazy.The weather has been great.If you have no symptoms, it’s hard to grasp why you can’t be out enjoying it.The Government always feared we would tire of a lockdown just as deaths were still peaking.That’s why they delayed it.Other nations are now relaxing theirs — that may prove disastrous.Home Secretary Priti Patel must get her tone right today.The public will not welcome threats about harsher restrictions.She must treat us like adults.Explain how vital it still is to keep the infection rate down, or deaths will soar again and perhaps swamp the NHS.But the Cabinet must bust a gut to work out how to safely release as many as possible from this house arrest in a fortnight.For now, heed the advice:Stay home, save lives. title: 5g coronavirus conspiracy theorist vodafone preacher luton
story: A CORONAVIRUS G conspiracy theorist who claimed to be a former Vodafone executive has been revealed to be a preacher from Luton.The claims were made on a widely circulated YouTube in which title: china coronavirus vaccine ready september
story: CHINA has claimed a coronavirus vaccine could be ready for use by September as the world searches for a cure.Dr Gao Fu, a leading virologist and head of Chinas Centre for Disease Control, predicted the inoculation could be ready for emergency use by the autumn.It comes as scientists the world over are attempting to develop a vaccine for Covid- - which has killed almost , people across the globe.Vaccines often take years to develop, but researchers are trying to achieve the goal in a matter of months.Dr Gao however was confident that China could role out the cure before the end of .He admitted however it would only be an emergency vaccine - with a wider shot available at the start of next year.Speaking on CGTN, Dr Gao said: It always takes time to develop a vaccine or a specic drug.He added safety of the general population must be a priority while developing the vaccine.The scientist was clear however the inoculation could be rolled out earlythere was another large scale outbreak.Dr Gao added the vaccine may be given to healthcare workers on the frontlineit was successful in tests.China claims it has two Covid- vaccines ready for clinical trials, and third which is still in development.Many scientists believe a vaccine is unlikely to be widely available until the middle of .Meanwhile, British scientists are beginning human trials of their own vaccine - the first of its kind in Europe.More than  people have been recruited for the study of the shot which was developed by the Oxford University.Brits however will not get first access to vaccines developed by taxpayer-funded UK universities due to a deal with the World Health Organisationannounced by foreign secretary Dominic Raab, reports the .This week, Dr Gao was forced the deny spreading misinformation about coronavirus this week as pressure continues on China.China is facing international pressure to open about the first few weeks of the outbreak - and whether or not virus could have been contained before becoming a pandemic.The top doc insisted he never, ever publicly denied that coronavirus could be transmitted between people during an interview with state media.WHO have also come under fire for their handling of the virus, with the US pulling funding and accusing them of being China-centric.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said reportedly wants to make sure Brits have access to the vaccine firstits developed within the UK.Speaking yesterday, Mr Hancock said: The upside of being the first country to develop a successful vaccine is so huge, I am throwing everything at it.The deal with WHO however means Britain will have to share its results and work with  other countries including France, Germany and Italy.US pharmaceutical company Inovio Pharmaceuticals, the University of Pennsylvania’s research facility, has also begun its own human trial.It comes as the global coronavirus infection figure surges towards million, with the US still the worst impacted nation in the world.US President Donald Trump has come under fire after he suggested disinfectant could be injected into victims to help cure Covid-.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. To claim your free packet of seeds, go to sunoffers sunflower and follow the simple instructions.Make sure you are quick as there are only , packets available on a first-come, first-served basis.Once you have ordered your free packet of seeds, they will be posted direct to you.sunoffers sunflowerPLACE your seeds half an inch deep into damp soil and they will be spouting ­in a couple of weeks.Sow two or three batches at three to four-week ­intervals to get a continuous stream of flowers.The shorter, quick-growing early kinds will be in flower in  to  days. The big ones will take longer.Or raise the seedlings indoors so the children can watch their progress. To do that, place seeds on a damp kitchen paper towel in a clean container.As soon as you see tiny roots emerge, plant them into small pots or trays of moist ­potting compost.Now they need full light and can go on to a window sill or patio table.Check regularly to see the compost does not dry out.Once they are six or more inches high they can be planted either in final containers or out in the garden.ASK children to draw a flower and they usually sketch out a sunflower – a single stem with yellow petals ­surrounding a dark central disc.Soyou’re aged under , show us your drawing skills and you could win a £ National Garden gt token.Send your colourful drawings or ­paintings to sunflowers@ the-sun by May , , and I will pick my top ten artists, who will each receive a £ token.We will also be giving away another ten vouchers for the best ­photos of your sunflowers when they start flowering this summer.Send those photographs to sunflowers@the-sun by September , .For full TCs here.BY paying attention to your garden, balcony, window sill – or even that unloved patch of ground down the road – you can unlock a host of benefits for yourself, your kids and your community.You can encourage wildle to thrive. Hedges, trees, flowers and even grass are havens for important critters, from birds and hedgehogs to frogs and beetles.You don’t need a sprawling estate to make a dference.One of the best things about sunflowers is their ability to absorb toxins. After the nuclear disasters at Hiroshima, Chernobyl and Fukushima, fields of sunflowers were planted to reduce toxic metals and radiation levels in the soil.They are also perfect for pollinating insects including bees and butterflies. And at the very end of their le they produce enough seeds to feed a flock of birds.There are plenty more simple ways we can help the environment from our gardens, too.Eating more fruit and veg and less meat is something we can all do. Tomatoes, beetroot, courgette and lettuce are easy to grow and can be sown indoors now and put on a sunny window sill to germinate. Use cardboard toilet roll tubes or egg boxes for this.Plant the seeds by following the packet instructions and keep them moist until they are ready to plant outside.Lettuce will grow just as easily indoors or on a balconyyou prick out the smaller seedlings to give the stronger ones more space.If herbs are your thing, include lemon balm. A few leaves steeped in hot water makes a fragrant tea that can help calm anxiety.Plant herbs as near to the kitchen as you can so you can grab a handful when you’re cooking.Plants and flowers provide food for nature but you can also build a home for frogs, ladybirds, beetles and other insects – it’s a great way for kids to see them up close.You don’t need anything fancy. Old bricks, bits of wood, logs, layers of cardboard, twigs, roof tiles or broken terracotta pots piled up in a semi-organised heap will do. The idea is to create lots of tiny, dferent-sized spaces for creatures to crawl into.Just be sure to put something waterproof on top to keep out the rain.You can even create a “hedgehog highway” by cutting a small hole – about the size of a CD – at the base of your fence on both sides of the garden. Encourage your neighbours to do the same, too, as hedgehogs like to roam large distances and this stops them getting penned in.If you haven’t got a garden, growing plants on your balcony or window sill can be just as beneficial for you and for nature.Andyou’re struggling for space there too, when you’re out on your daily exercise take note of unused bits of ground – around the base of street trees, on roadside verges, abandoned empty planters – that might benefit from a bit of colour.Plant your sunflower seeds there and watch them grow as you walk, run or cycle past each day.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc news mistakes brighton pavilion
story: During a live TV report on Ramadan, blundering TV producers at BBC Wales used a picture of the royal retreat.But eagle-eyed viewers spotted the gaffe instantly and some were not happy about it.One complained online: “BBC Wales showing a picture of the Brighton Pavilion and getting it confused for a mosque when talking about Ramadan is kind of f****d ” In fact Brighton Pavilion was a seaside retreat for King George IV.Another said: “Not happy theyve used a shot of Brighton Pavilion as though its a mosque .”A third responded: “Oooooh now I see it. Tbh I dont blame them, it does look like a masjid.”Once a modest farmhouse, it was transformed into its full glory between  to .The architecture is Indian-inspired – and the building was used as a hospital in World War One.The English Defence League famously made the same mistake in , when members voiced their disgust at finding a “giant mosque” while marching in the city.And in , an aide of Ed Miliband reportedly cancelled a photoshoot outside the Pavilion in anticipation of exactly the same mistake being made.Embarrassed BBC chiefs apologised for the gaffe.They said it was a mistake due to the incorrect labelling of a picture.A spokesman for BBC Wales said: “This was a mistake for which we apologise”.Ramadan started on April, ,  meaning that the UKs three million Muslims will have to fast and celebrate the holy month during lockdown.Many of the traditions around Ramadan involve gathering together, community work and charity, which has to be compromised due to social distancing restrictions.New guidance released by The Muslim Council of Britainhas outlined how Muslims can practise their faith during the holy month while keeping safe from coronavirus.The MCB recommends that families organise taraweeh at home and pray in congregation, stream Islamic lectures and arrange virtual tars with loved ones.Communal worship is not allowed due to social distancing.However, you can still join in online with your local mosque or the wider community.As with all other religious and communal areas and events, mosques and prayer facilities are shut during lockdown.While it is not possible for mosques to serve tar on their premises or as a group, many are providing boxed food for those that are in need within the wider community, including NHS staff.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bank of england coronavirus work loans
story: CORONAVIRUS is affecting everyone’s lives right now.Whatever you are doing — a key worker, isolating at home or attempting to home school — we all have a role to play in overcoming this disease.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.And that goes for the Bank of England, too.The virus and the measures taken to stop it spreading are dramatically reducing activity in the economy.So what is the Bank of England doing to help The Bank’s job now, as always, is to provide monetary and financial stability.We do that in a number of ways, such as ensuring your money maintains its value by keeping inflation low and stable.We also support the economy to help keep as many people in work as possible.Given the challenges facing us all, the Bank has launched an unprecedented package of measures to support the UK economy.These measures will help as far as possible to keep ­companies running and hard-working people in their jobs.In this way, the Bank can help prevent coronavirus from causing long-lasting economic harm to Britain.Firstly, we have cut our interest rate to a historic low of . per cent.Lower interest rates mean cheaper loans for businesses and households.Secondly, we are injecting a further £billion into the economy to help cut long-term borrowing costs.Thirdly, we are supporting businesses’ access to cash.We are working closely with the Treasury to support large businesses and their workers by offering them loans for up to  months.We have already committed £billion to help firms pay wages and their suppliers.Fourthly, we are helping banks to continue lending to UK households and firms.We require banks and building societies to hold financial buffers, known as capital, so they can withstand any losses on loans they make.But we are temporarily allowing lenders to hold less capital.This will support up to £billion of bank lending to businesses.To put that into perspective, it is more than  times the amount they lent to businesses in the whole of .Throughout this period, my colleagues have continued to run the core payment system that allows you to use your credit and debit cards.We process payments equivalent to UK GDP, or £.trillion, every three days.And we are keeping our eyes open for any risks that might emerge to the economy or the financial system as this pandemic unfolds.No one can be sure exactly how the coronavirus pandemic will unfold and that goes for us, too.But one thing you can be sure of is that my colleagues and I at the Bank of England will do all we can to support everyone through this dficult time.We’ve got your back.That’s our duty.We have already delivered a huge package of measures.And we stand ready to do whatever we can to meet your needs and get through this together.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meccas grand mosque deserted lockdown
story: The Saudi Arabian mosque attracts more than million Muslims every year during the three weeks of Ramadan.The images show the mosque nearly empty with barriers in place for the small amount of Muslims allowed in to pray during the first day.Workers entered the Kaaba before worshippers arrived to disinfect the area to stop the potential spread of the virus.Across the world, Muslims are unable to pray in mosques due to lockdown measures imposed worldwide.Although countries dfer on the strict nature of those measures, religious gatherings have been banned.Several countries have eased restrictions on the occasion of the holy month with Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and other countries reducing the duration of the lockdowns.The UAE said yesterday it has decided to ease the total lockdown to an eight-hour nightly curfew and also moved to partially reopen malls and markets.The . billion Muslims worldwide will celebrate the holy month, which includes communal prayer, isolated or socially separated in mosques.Mosques that are usually brimming with the faithful are closed this Ramadan including in Saudi Arabia, home to Mecca and Medina, the holiest cities in Islam.So far the kingdom has , positive coronavirus cases with more than  deaths.In a statement, Saudi King Salman bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud lamented the necessity to maintain social distancing to halt the spread of the novel coronavirus and the damper it would place on this years celebrations.It pains me to welcome the glorious month of Ramadan under circumstances that forbid us of prayers in Mosques and of performing the Ramadan prayers, he said, according to the official Saudi Press Agency.All this is due to the protective measures taken to save lives and human well-being in light of the global threat of COVID-.The UKs three million Muslims started observing the holy month of Ramadan last night.Ramadan marks the month when the Quran was revealed to Prophet Muhammad by Allah.The holy month will see Muslims around the world fasting during daylight hours for  days.All Muslims who have reached puberty are expected to fast during Ramadan, although there are some exceptions.Women who are menstruating or pregnant and those suffering from illness do not have to fast.The rules mean food and drink, including water, are not allowed during daylight hours for the entire month. The Islamic calendar is based around the lunar cycle, the holy month of Ramadan rotates by approximately ten days each year.The month is confirmed with the sighting of the new moon.Muslims then celebrate with a massive -hour party involving family and friends called the feast of Eid al-Fitr.This celebration is marked with lights, decorations and gts, with worshippers often dressing up and decorating their homes.Sadly,lockdown is still in place by then, these parties will have to be familial events or will need to take place online through video chats.The MCB is offering guidance on how to organise virtual tars online with loved ones and members of the community via video chat.

title: downing street no deal michel barnier uk not equal eu
story: But the  EU’s chief negotiator blasted Britain for ruling out a longer transition while dragging its feet on fishing rights.Both sides blamed the other for refusing to compromise on key points as a second round of talks ended in stalemate.Mr Barnier said the UK was “failing to engage” and a deal was no closer than before.The EUs chief negotiator fumed: The UK cannot impose this short timeline, and at the same time not budge on the same topics that are of importance to the EU.There will be no trade agreement without an agreement on fisheries. title: brit jihadi identified by his ears
story: Abdel-Majed Abdel Bary, a wannabe rapper from London who joined IS in Syria in , was held with two ­others when a flat was raided on Monday.But police were satisfied they had the right man only after comparing file images with surveillance ­pictures taken outside the rented apartment in Almeria.Bary, , had put on six stone and took advantage of the coronavirus lockdown to hide his face behind a mask on the rare occasions he left the property.But a police source told Spanish daily paper El Pais: “The shape of his ears was one of the things that enabled us to identy him.”His identity was confirmed later from fingerprints.Bary, the Egyptian-born son of a jihadi fanatic jailed for bomb attacks on US embassies in Africa, was making his name as a rapper and was played on Radio .But after joining IS he was seen holding up a severed head in a picture posted online.It is thought he sneaked into Spain by boat a few days before his arrest. title: britain coronavirus lockdown eased clusters gatherings
story: LOCKDOWN rules could be eased to allow people to socialise with ten of their closest family and friends.Ministers are reportedly looking at easing strict stay at home rules in favour of creating groups of people known as clusters or bubbles.The clusters will be small groups of households with no more than ten people who can socialise somewhat freely, reports the Daily Mail.And then those people inside the group will still be unable to mingle with the general public as before the coronavirus lockdown.Despite hope for Brits, Home Secretary Priti Patel will warn today thatpeople continue to flout lockdown measure, rules will be made stricter.It is hoped the potential easing would allow close family members to meet for meals, allow couples who do not live together to see each other, and allow friends to share childcare.Ministers are said to want to prevent a free-for-all which could allow the pandemic to take hold again in a second wave.Brits would nominate a list of people they want to be able to see, drawn from no more than one or two households.Government officials are still trying to thrash out how such a system would work as plans begin to be drawn up about how to ease the lockdown.Pictures have emerged this week of growing numbers of people heading outside, with road traffic up  per cent.Britain entered the coronavirus lockdown on March , and some European nations are beginning to ease measures.Ministers however are reportedly gloomy about any signicant easing of the lockdown on May , needing to meet five key tests including slashing the number of cases and securing regular supplies of PPE.Currently the UK rules state that people should not meet up with anyone they do not live with.And people continue to be urged to stay inside and only go out for essentials such as food shopping or daily exercise.Over the past few days however drivers were seen queuing at a Costa Coffee in Mansfield, and hundreds of people flocked to the seafront in Hove, East Sussex.Menawhile, shoppers gathered at a BM in Basildon, Essex, and people were seen drinking on Hampstead Heath in London.Prime Minister Boris Johnson is reportedly fearful of a second wave and is reluctant to be hasty in easing lockdown measures - despite pressure from inside the Cabinet.It comes after Nicola Sturgeon, First Minister of Scotland, also suggested lockdown measures could be eased with bubbles of friends.Ms Sturgeon told BBC Radio Scotland’s Good Morning Scotland: Some countries are starting to look at slightly expanding what people would define as their household – encouraging people who live alone to maybe match up with somebody  who is on their own or a couple of other people to have almost kind of bubbles of people.The First Minister added: Now, none of these are fixed decisions yet, but these are all the kind of things we’re trying to work through.”She stressed the strict measures were still absolutely necessary, but said Scotland needs to chart a way forward to live with the virus over the coming monthsHealth secretary Matt Hancock warned the government would not ease lockdown restrictions until it was certain they could prevent a devastation second wave of infection.Britains death toll rose today to ,, while the total confirmed cases is now , - with the worldwide figures sitting at , deaths and almost million cases.The race is on to find a vaccine, with human trials kicking off in the UK today led by a team from Oxford University.Meanwhile, bored Brits could get a boost as plans are finalised for theof the Premier League behind closed doors.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The title: sausage dog toy washing machine
story: The three-year-old dachshund barked and scratched at the washer for an hour while waiting for the chicken drumstick, which he takes to bed every night in Glossop, Derbys.Mum-of-one Rebekah, , had to hide treats in the garden just so she could ‘sneak’ the toy into the wash - but Pickle managed to snf it out before she’d even turned on the machine.Rebekah said: “I don’t know how Pickle could smell his toy through the washing machine door but he found it straight away.“He started barking at me.“It was like he was saying, ‘Oh my god, do you know that my toy is in the washing machine  You need to get it out’.“He definitely thinks I can speak sausage dog.“The cycle was on for an hour and he sat there the whole time.“Even when he couldn’t see his toy anymore, he still knew it was in there.“As soon as I opened the door, he saw it but he didn’t knowhe was allowed to take it yet so he was carefully touching it with his nose.“I told him he could take it and he got it out the machine and walked off. He was over the moon to have it back.”As well as Pickle, estate agent Rebekah and her family share their home with four other Dachshunds.Pooches Pepper, six, Peanut, five, Petal, four, Twiglet, one, and Pickle keep the family on their toes and constantly entertained with their inidual personalities. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: postman delivers parcel to somewhere in sheffield
story: Darrell Gilmour, , saw a description of the recipient, “David” written on the package.It said he had “a child, or a dog, or both”, used to work as a BBC sports reporter and had a we called Helen.Darrell eventually traced David Easson, , on social media.Sender Marten Wedebrand, , from Sweden, used to listen to David’s reports and send chocolate to the studio staff.The parcel, labelled “vital survival stuff”, contained six bars of Kvikk Lunsj, a Norwegian chocolate the BBC man liked.It also contained a note saying: Please try and find him and give this to him and dear postman stay safe.Surprised David said: “It made me proud of the postal service.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: south africas president cyril ramaphosa face mask coronavirus
story: SOUTH Africa’s President Cyril Ramaphosa struggled to put on a facemask on after delivering a speech on the importance of wearing them.Hilarious video shows the President attempting to get the elastic around his ears but only managing to cover his face.“We are calling on all South Africans to wear a face mask, whenever you leave home,” he exhorted the nation.“Our clothing and textile industry, including small businesses, are gearing up to produce these masks on a mass scale. Let us continue staying safe.“And thank you for what you have done and continue to do. May God continue to bless South Africa and continue to protect her people.”But was meant to be a dramatic, leading-by-example putting on of a mask, instead ended comically as he went to put a one on.After fumbling around for a few seconds the President managed to get one over his face and said “thank you”.His mask fail led to widespread mockery on social media and the hashtags #MaskOnChallenge and #CyrilMaskChallenge trending on Twitter.President appeared to take the mockery in good humour and managed to joke about what happened later.“Well for those of you who were laughing at me yesterday, I am going to open a TV channel where Im going to teach people to put on a mask, he said.So you can enroll how a mask is put on.”South Africa went into a -day coronavirus lockdown on March  and this has since been extended with most people urged to stay at home.The total ban on cigarette sells will also be eased from next month though a total ban on alcohol sale and transportation remains in place.Some schools are expected to reopen with limitations placed on class sizes.Most restrictions aimed at containing the virus and limiting transmissions will remain in place.These include the ban on local and international travel, except for the repatriation of South Africans who are still stuck abroad.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast heatwave end
story: April showers are expected to sweep in, leading the Environment Agency to warn flooding is possible in the south of England.April has seen gorgeous sunshine and warm temperatures, tempting Brits to sunbathe in parks and on beaches despite pleas to stay inside.But this weekend, temperatures will begin to fall and the cooler weather will continue into next week.Met Office meteorologist Craig Snell said: On Saturday, another largely dry day, but on the eastern coast and in the south-west of England and Wales we may see some cloud.“This could trigger the odd shower, but they are expected to be brief.Temperatures on Saturday will continue to stay relatively high at  or  C and other parts of Britain should get the sun.The Met Office website said: Another fine, warm and dry day for most with some long sunny spells.Cloudier for some north and east coasts of Scotland, cooler here and along North Sea coasts. The chance of the odd shower in Wales.Dry and bright periods, though some coastal fog patches and also some showers for many areas. Warm in the south, cooler in the north.A few showers for the south-west and Wales,  most places dry with warm sunny spells after low cloud clears, but remaining dull and misty near some coasts.Across the south of England, eight flood warnings put in place for over the weekend.Just some of the possible areas have been marked for flooding are the Alton area, High Wycombe area, Salisbury Plain area and West Ilsley and surrounding areas.Sunday will bring more rain adding to the warnings for flooding in some areas.Mr Snell added: “Sunday will be the day it changes, temperatures will be slowly falling away from that point.“We will see a band of showers working their way from Scotland to England during the day.“London and the south-west wont see showers until the evening.The further north you are, the sooner youll see showers. Northern England and Wales will have rain from about lunchtime.For some, this is the first spot of rain for a while. As the showers come, the temperatures will tumble.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus tests key workers website
story: CORONAVIRUS home and drive-through tests for key workers have been snapped up within one hour today as thousands flock to the website.By .am the governments website told hopefuls the applications for DIY kits were closed while drive-through tests were booked out by .am.However, more slots are expected to be released throughout the day.Key workers and their families are still able to book a test by visiting a regional site in Scotland.The website had last night been closed after exceptional demand with the bookings to reopen at am today.But Transport Secretary Grant Shapps insisted the site had not crashed.He told the Downing Street: It looks like the trajectory to , tests by the end of April is going to be met in terms of capacity.I would say, after today, the demand is there, sothose two things come together we will have it being met.About , tests have already been booked through the website.Criticism has been levelled over a series of test shambles in the UK - as drive-through sites for NHS tests were pictured looking empty and some results were found to be inaccurate.Frustrated people trying to get hold of tests complained the process was complicated and they couldnt find a category for their job role.Health Secretary Matt Hancock had claimed it was as easy as booking a flight but many said they got error messages as the website struggled to cope.He had announced on Thursday that seven million of Englands key workers and their families could get coronavirus tests.The radical new plans mean that essential workers including teachers, bankers or supermarket workers were invited for testing.For Brits without a car, home testing kits, including swabs and instructions, were made available to order online.Those who were first to get their hands on one will have them delivered by Amazon within the next  hours before being collected by the Royal Mail the next day - with results promises within  hours of collection.At least  million people are thought to qualy for the tests now, No think, and thousands will be able to go back to worktheirs comes back negative.Professor John Newton said that the Governments target to test , people a day by the end of the month was still on track, despite just , taking place yesterday.There are now dozens of drive through testing sites available across the country, but workers have told how they have to drive hours to get there.There are plans to set up around  testing centres like this in the coming weeks. Those who cant get there will be able to access mobile testing units, or get them sent to their doors.The five ways key workers and their families can get a test are:The Department of Health and Social Care are currently supporting  NHS trusts with satellite test sites for their staff .A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.Brits were last night warned that the coronavirus lockdown wont be ltedthey flout rules.Mr Shapps said the answer of when the measures will be altered is in your own hands.The Transport Secretary, speaking at Friday nights government press conference, praised the nation for adhering to social distancing rules.But he said the peak isnt over and urged people to continue to stay at home.He said: The country has done incredibly well in adhering to social distancing and there is a danger as we go into yet another warm sunny weekend that people think that perhaps these graphs are showing that the peak is over.It isnt over, were riding perhaps, we hope, a downward trend but it is by no means, no means established yet.When people ask me when will the measures, the social distancing, the stay at home measures, be altered, my answer in some ways is that some of this lies in your own hands.It came as Brits appeared to be cracking under the strain of the lockdown, with traffic on the roads creeping up by  per cent.Drivers were seen queuing at a Costa Coffee in Mansfield, hundreds of people flocked to the seafront in Hove, East Sussex, shoppers gathered at a BM in Chelmsford, Essex, and people were seen drinking on Hampstead Heath in London.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - title: coronavirus dominic cummings involved secretive
story: NewsCoronavirus: Dominic Cummings attended meetings of science  advising UK governmentThe government faces "signicant questions" after it was revealed Dominic Cummings, Boris Johnsons chief adviser, attended a key meeting of the Scientic Advisory Group for EmergenciesShareCommentsByGavin CordonAnna MacSwan:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsCummings was on a leaked list of Sage attendees " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Dominic Cummings, the Prime Ministeraposs chief adviser, has been taking part in meetings held by the secretive scientic group which advises ministers on coronavirus. Mr Cummings was one of  attendees at a key meeting of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencieson March , the day Boris Johnson announced the nationwide lockdown, according to a list leaked to the . Ben Warner, a data scientist who worked on the Vote Leave campaign during the Brexit referendum, is also understood to have been present.The revelation yesterday evening has raised signicant questions about the independence of the scientic advice given by Sage. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here A former government chief scientic adviser, Sir David King, said he was shocked to find that there were political advisers involved. If you are giving science advice, your advice should be free of any political bias. That is just so critically important, he told the . A No spokesman confirmed Mr Cummings had attended Sage meetings but denied he was a member of the group. Sage provides independent scientic advice to the Government. Political advisers have no role in this, they said. The scientists on Sage are among the most eminent in their fields. It is factually wrong and damaging to sensible public debate to imply their advice is affected by government advisers listening to discussions. Downing Street say that Mr Cummings had attended some Sage meetings and listened to some meetings now they are all virtual. He and another adviser do this in order to understand better the scientic debates concerning this emergency and also to understand better the limits of how science and data can help government decisions, the spokesman added. Occasionally they ask questions or offer help when scientists mention problems in Whitehall.  The Government is under increasing pressure to reveal who sits on Sage given its critical role giving advice on how to tackle the coronavirus crisis. It has never released a list of the aposs members of attendees, although iniduals are free to disclose they are part of the group. In a letter to Parliament earlier this month, Sir Patrick Vallance, the UKaposs chief scientic adviser and chair of Sage, said the group does not disclose its membership on the advice of the Centre for the Protection of National Infrastructure . He said this is for security reasons, and to protect members from lobbying and other forms of unwanted influence. Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth said the disclosure that Mr Cummings had been attending Sage raised signicant questions about the credibility of Government decision-making. Dominic Cummings has no place on the Governmentaposs scientic advisory group on the coronavirus, he said. He is a political adviser, not a medical or scientic expert. If the public are to have confidence in the Sage, the Government must make clear Dominic Cummings can no longer participate or attend.

story: NewsCoronavirus law change will hand new mums full maternity pay - even on furloughThe last-minute change in the law will apply to anyone starting Maternity, Paternity, Shared Parental, Bereavement or Adoption Pay from tomorrow - but campaigners say it doesnt go far enoughShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR News" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Mother-and-a-baby.jpg"The change will mean people who go on maternity leave now receive their full usual maternity pay " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA last-minute change in the law has been enacted today to stop new mums losing out in the coronavirus outbreak. The change will mean people who go on maternity leave now receive their full usual maternity pay, eventhey are put on the governmentaposs aposfurloughapos scheme. It applies to anyone starting Maternity, Paternity, Shared Parental, Parental Bereavement or Adoption Pay from tomorrow. Tonightaposs move - which campaigners said was welcome, but not enough - comes after fears that thousands of mums were losing out on cash. The aposfurloughapos scheme for more than million people leaves workers on % or less of their usual pay, funded by the state. Because maternity pay is already less than a full wage, new mums were taking a double hit by having their salary docked, and then ided again when they went on leave. Under the new law, anyone who starts maternity leave from tomorrow will now have it based on their usual earnings - not the reduced wage they got on furlough. That means it will be worth at least % of usual earnings for the first  weeks, followed by  weeks at the statutory rate which is currently £.. Business Minister Paul Scully said: These measures will ensure those on the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme continue to receive the parental leave and pay they are entitled to. However, the change stops short of demands by the campaign group Maternity Action, which wrote to the Chancellor earlier this month. Todayaposs announcement does not address the plight of pregnant women who feel forced to leave their work by government guidance on vulnerable groups. Pregnant women, along with the over-s and people with an underlying health condition, are being told to signicantly limit face-to-face contact. The government has said the move is a precaution while scientists work outpregnant women are more at risk. But Maternity Action says many pregnant women are still being directed to work, in unsafe conditions, during the pandemic. The group is demanding formal advice for employers to offer home working or other safe working conditions for those women, or  allow them to be suspended on full pay. Director Rosalind Bragg said the move was welcome but did not go far enough. She said: We are still waiting for the Government to provide employers with clear guidance on health and safety for pregnant women.

It would also mean couples who do not live together can spend time together. Yesterday Ms Sturgeon published a -page document saying outdoor activities might resume, and businesses may reopenthey can keep customers and staff  metres apart. The First Minister also suggested schools could reopen with modications needed in some classrooms. Health Secretary Matt Hancock has refused to comment in detail on the plan for the whole of the UK.
